skill_name: Ask My Kid - Remote Learning Activities
skill_description: Designed to help students and kids learn and study at home. Teachers and parents love having the extra support during busy days and evenings with AskMyKid. Whether kids are distance and remote learning or after a full day at school, kids often struggle to focus on study and homework. To support, AskMyKid has brain breaks, timers, academic practice, and emotional support activities. Teachers and parents can instantly add their own activities too. To learn how visit and see the full list of commands, go to:  https://askmykid.com/activities For example: - Need to get students to refocus for homework? Say “Alexa, calm down with my kid" or "Alexa, ask my kid to calm down" - Need to get their wiggles out? “Alexa, dance with my kid” or "Alexa, ask my kid to dance" - Want to build their attention muscle? “Alexa, mindfulness with my kid” or " Alexa, ask my kid for mindfulness" - Want a timer? “Alexa, 2-minute music countdown with my kid” or "Alexa, ask my kid for a 2-minute music countdown" - How about calm music during work time? “Alexa, background music with my kid” or "Alexa, ask my kid for background music" Either start the command with "ask my kid" or end with "with my kid". Learn more: At AskMyClass, we believe in making education more empowering and engaging, using affordable tools, so every child learns better. Voice technology and AI are skills that all kids will be interacting with when they enter the workforce in 10 years, and we’re keen on getting them ready for that future. Visit us at GoAskMyClass.com.  If you’re a teacher looking for AskMyClass - Classroom Edition - search the skills store or learn more here: GoAskMyClass.com. If you’ve got content ideas or constructive feedback just email team@goaskmyclass.com. We’d love to hear from you.

skill_name: King Minister Thief Police - Popular indoor game
skill_description: The game begins with making 4 chits namely Raja or king (1000 points) , Mantri or minister (800 points) , Chor or thief ( 0 points) and Sipahi or police (500 points). Each chit is randomly picked by alexa against the 4 players.Alexa discloses the raja or king and sipahi or police. The sipahi or police, then has to identify the ‘Chor’ or the thief, from the other 2 remaining players. If the sipahi or police, guesses correctly then the points are retained or else he/she surrenders them to the Chor or thief. Several rounds of this game are played before counting the points. The player with the highest score wins the game. The default winner is the player who reaches 10000 points first. The game helps develop cognitive thinking by requiring deductive reasoning. This entertaining game can be learned quickly and is a tool to make new friends. This game provides a platform for social interaction and enhances communication skills. Keywords - Raja Mantri Chor Sipahi, King, Minister, Thief, Police, indoor, game, four player game, cognitive thinking, social, friends, enhances communication skill, kids, adult, Raja Mantri Chor Sipahi, King, Minister, Thief, Police, indoor, game, four player game, cognitive thinking, social, friends, enhances communication skill, kids, adult, Raja Mantri Chor Sipahi, King, Minister, Thief, Police, indoor, game, four player game, cognitive thinking, social, friends, enhances communication skill, kids, adult, Raja Mantri Chor Sipahi, King, Minister, Thief, Police, indoor, game, four player game, cognitive thinking, social, friends, enhances communication skill, kids, adult, Raja Mantri Chor Sipahi, King, Minister, Thief, Police, indoor, game, four player game, cognitive thinking, social, friends, enhances communication skill, kids, adult

This skill is was created with the goal in mind of aiding teachers of young students in teaching listening skills through the use of the "turn and talk" method, which is described as follows. The teacher begins by pairing each student up. Each child then turns to their partner, and then the teacher provides each student with a question. Each student then takes a turn answering the question. This method is implemented by providing the students with a random question, a timer so each student knows when their time to talk is done, and also introduces a series of verbal cues that a teacher would introduce to her students prior to use that help to keep children on task. Using the skill is fairly simple. To start the skill, say something to the effect of "Alexa, ask Classchat to give us a question", and Alexa will begin by saying, "Okay everyone, 1, 2, 3, knee to knee!" This is one of the aforementioned verbal cues, and is the "turn" part of "turn and talk". At this point, each child would be asked to face their partner. Alexa will then ask a random question from the question database provided. After Alexa asks the question, an internal timer will begin, and this is where a teacher would direct her students to begin to answer the question to one another. The default time is set to 3 minutes, and Alexa will announce when time is halfway finished so the other partner can begin to speak. Once time is up, Alexa will say "3, 2, 1, talking is done!", which is another verbal cue meant to return the attention to the teacher. It will then ask the kids to give a "thumbs up" if they demonstrated a key communication skill, such as making good eye contact. You can ask Alexa to provide a question that is more focused on a specific topic by saying something like "ask Classchat to give us a question about respect". The different topics you can currently choose from are: reading, our strengths, each other, respect, and school. You can also adjust the time allotted for the question by saying something like "ask Classchat for question for 2 minutes". A number of different phrasings have been included in the intent schema in order to provide for many different teaching scenarios.

Autism Help is designed for parents and caregivers who are busy and overwhelmed, to use the convenience of Amazon's Echo device to teach functional, social and verbal skills. You will be offered skills to work on,  with each step of that skill provided. You can work on multiple areas at a time, and Alexa will track your progress.   There's applause to reward children as they complete each step, and music to ease the stress of completing a step. Why Autism Skills? I want to see children with autism grow and express their creativity and realize their dreams. I don't want the lack of verbal, functional or social skills to hold them back! A little every day makes a huge difference. Try Autism Skills...one skill at a time!

As a parent myself, I understand that nothing is more important than the well being of your children.  Everyday, kids are bombarded with messages that are detrimental to their happiness, confidence and self esteem. I built this simple skill for my son to ensure that he starts every day feeling confident, happy, calm and ready to have the best day he can. Try it for a while with your kids too and watch as their confidence, self esteem and happiness grows. This skill itself is very simple. The idea behind it is very powerful. Kids repeat 6 randomly chosen, positive affirmations about themselves. It takes about one minute to complete. Positive affirmations have an extraordinary effect on children - They help to inspire, motivate, and build confidence and self-esteem. When kids use positive affirmations from an early age they'll reap a lifetime of benefits. A really great way to start or end their day! This skill never collects any personal data. If you have suggestions to improve the skill, please let me know in the comments. Thanks and have a great day!

Ever wonder how to get your child to finish his or her homework on time and learn time management, instead of wasting time on watching Youtube or playing games? Meet Miss Arcade, your child’s best friend that will teach them about self discipline and motivate them to do assigned tasks. Miss Arcade is an Alexa skill that targets children in elementary school (ages 6 - 10) with the goal of improving habits and introducing them to money management by earning stars and spending them on prizes. Both parents and their children interact with the skill. Our skill is based on an engaging task system that rewards good habits and promotes self-discipline. It is like an arcade game, but for completing real tasks and earning real-life rewards. Parents are able to set a number of tasks for their children, and specify how many “stars” they will receive on completion. Stars can be redeemed for prizes (like candy or TV time), which the parent also specifies with the Miss Arcade skill. When the child is done, they can report to their parent and the adult can mark the task as completed. Cheating will not be possible, as parents can check which tasks were completed recently and have the ability to reverse it. Both child and parent can ask Miss Arcade what the current star count is and what tasks there are left. This way, tasks can be self driven and done throughout the day, while homework can be done without a parent pestering the kid! By using this skill, children are able to learn more about time management and the rewards of completing work in a timely manner. Additionally, they'll have to save their stars for more valuable prize, introducing financial skills.  Unlike other Alexa skills or mobile apps, Miss Arcade is made specifically for kids and provides the type of fun experience that will help kids continue to engage with Alexa and establish strong foundations for time-management skills.  Process:  - Add prizes (movies, video game time, etc.) to Miss Arcade (parents) and describe how many stars it will take to redeem. Ex. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade to add reward. Quantities are not stored for prizes, though they can be removed at any time.  - Add tasks (homework, housework) to Miss Arcade (parents) and describe what the task is and how many stars the child will earn after completing it. Ex. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade to add task. Tasks can be duplicated and removed.  - List tasks and rewards in Miss Arcade (child) and choose one task to work on. Ex. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade to list tasks. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade to list prizes. - The child completes the task and gets stars for rewards.  Ex. Alexa, tell Miss Arcade that homework is now finished. - The child can redeem prizes with his or her stars. Ex. Alexa, tell Miss Arcade to redeem prize. The parents will give the reward to the child. Other features: - Check how many stars the child has. Ex. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade how many stars I have. - Remove task in the task list. Ex. Alexa, tell Miss Arcade to cancel homework. - Remove prize in the task list. Ex. Alexa, tell Miss Arcade to remove prize. - Check what the child has finished in the last 24 hours. Ex. Alexa, ask  Miss Arcade what has been done today.  - Uncomplete any task (parents) in case the child lied. Ex. Alexa, ask Miss Arcade to mark homework uncomplete. Coming features: - Deadlines for tasks and give bonus stars if finished in time. - Streaks for finishing multiple tasks in a row or meet a certain expectation. - Weekly reports on the child’s progress.

Kids Decisions allows kids from Kindergarten to 5th grade to explore how different decisions impact the outcome of a story. Ember the Dragon guides kids along the exploration path with quick, engaging stories and opportunities for kids to try out different decisions and explore outcomes. Based on Strengths and Virtues, kids can explore stories related to Wisdom, Courage, Humanity, Transcendence, Justice, and Moderation. To start a Kids Decision session, you can ask, Alexa, open Kids Decisions. You can also ask, Alexa, ask Kids Decisions to tell me a story.  You can ask for specific topics and see if Ember has a story for you. For example, you can ask, Alexa, ask Kids Decisions to tell me a story about chocolate.  You can ask for specific virtues and Ember will tell you a story related to that virtue. For example, you can ask, Alexa, ask Decisions for Kids to tell me a story about courage.  Decisions for Kids has a website, http://decisionsforkids.com/, where teachers and parents can craft and submit stories that Ember will use.

Every day, Lincoln Loud has to work through the chaos of his house to get anything done. But now, you can help him in The Loud House Challenge! Follow Lincoln around the house as he tries to help his sisters—Lori, Leni, Luna, Luan, Lynn, Lucy, Lana, Lola, Lisa and Lily—with all the crazy curveballs they throw at him. You’ll help Lincoln gather supplies for an epic sleepover, remake a birthday cake that fell on the floor, and get Lily to take her nap! Can you and Lincoln save the day in the Loud House? As someone who has a child with sensory processing disorder, we often need to utilize different strategies to help calm down during a meltdown or in crowds. These are similar strategies Occupational Therapists use to help people with anxiety and sensory processing disorders. When helping our child with these strategies, we found that it also really helped adults as well.  These strategies help with anger episodes, anxiety, meltdowns, tension. Even if you do not have any of  diagnoses, this information can still be very helpful. Anytime any of these situations begin, just say "Alexa, open calm down," and a helpful strategy will be provided to help calm down. Between our echo devices and echo auto, it makes using this skill helpful in many areas.

Nanak Time is dedicated to anyone who wants to live a beautiful and purposeful life. Inspired from the Mool Mantar composed by Guru Nanak Dev Ji, this app explores universal concepts such as Oneness, Truthful Living and living Without Fear and Hate. Specifically created to work around your busy lifestyle, the app allows you to: * Explore the 9 Gems of Mool Mantar by listening to short Audio Lessons and Guided Meditations * Apply the essence of the Gems to your daily life with simple-to-follow guides and hands-on exercises *Journal your thoughts and experiences * Use the reminders to keep you on track to complete your lessons * Enjoy the ripple effect of the simple exercises designed to impact the community around you Guru Nanak Dev Ji was the first of ten Sikh Guru’s and was born in 1469. He composed many sublime poems through a lifetime of traveling the globe and sharing his enlightened message of Ek Onkar, Oneness. The Mool Mantar is said to be the first composition uttered by Guru Nanak Dev Ji upon enlightenment at the age of about 30. The word ""Mool"" means main or root and ""Mantar"" means chant or verse. Together the words ""Mool Mantar"" mean the ""Main chant"" or ""root verse"" The Mool Mantar is regarded by many as the thesis of his work. Often described as just a summary of the Divine, the Mool Mantar is actually considered to define and carry a deep implication for human existence. Each of the 9 words (Gems) encompass a truly global concept of habits, traits and mindset we should aim to achieve. By explaining the theories and suggesting practical ways to integrate each of the concepts into your daily life, Nanak Time intends to get you started on this journey of discovery and self-reflection. You can pause and play by saying "Alexa, pause" and "Alexa, resume." Just say "Alexa, stop" when you're done for the day. When listening to podcasts you can say "Alexa, shuffle" to shuffle the playing order, or "Alexa, loop" to loop the current episode. You can also ask for previous and next episodes by saying "Alexa, previous" and "Alexa, next".

Ever performed in the circus with a Swizzle Stomp monster? Or helped a baby sea monster get to sleep? From Sesame Workshop and HBO, the Esme & Roy skill brings the lively characters of the new animated series to your home. Monstersitting pros Esme and Roy will take your kids on pretend play adventures from the moon to a hot air balloon, encouraging children to move their bodies and use their imaginations to join the fun! Ballyland™ Flight is a fun, educational game for young children. The story takes them to the popular Ballyland, an imaginary world that is home to the Ballylanders, created by Sonokids®. This is where they will find Ballicopter, the little red helicopter, flying high through the skies, on his way to visit one of his friends. What will happen and how his adventure will develop, will be decided by the children! They are encouraged to use simple words to select twists in the story, developing voice control interaction with Alexa in a safe environment.  This game was created by experienced audio game developers and is particularly rich in audio. It uses a well-known voice for narration, includes two original songs that your children may want to move, sing, or dance along with, and offers great sound effects that will capture their imagination. Young children who are blind or visually impaired will also be able to enjoy and engage with this story, building self-confidence in the use of voice control technology.  “Every day is a Ballyland day, and a Ballyland day is a happy day!” The game helps to develop: • Simple voice commands to use smart speaker technology with voice control • Language skills • Choice Making skills • Concept of Cause & Effect • Concept of sequencing • Concepts such as nice/bad, slow/fast, grumpy/happy  • Singing and moving along to songs • Recognizing musical instruments and styles

skill_name: The Case of the Missing Canine
skill_description: "The Case of the Missing Canine" is the first story in The Doggie Investigation Gang, DIG™ series of children's books. The intended audience is second to fourth grade students. While learning third-grade level vocabulary, speaker dialogue and being introduced to chapter books, the reader follows three main dog characters, one of which is blind, as they solve mysteries in an effort to assist others. The three dogs are different breeds and have diverse skill sets. The series incorporates many hidden lessons, including the value of individual strengths and differences; the importance of teamwork; and the reward of caring for each other and assisting others in a time of need. All profits from sales of the first book will be donated to PAWS New England to assist in rescuing the dogs residing at Tipton County Animal Shelter, a high-kill shelter located in Tipton, TN. For more information on the DIG Series, visit the DIG website at digthebooks.com Credits: Shara Puglisi Katsos (Author), John Bulens (Illustrator), Karen Talbot (Illustrator), Chris Plankey (Developer)
Tell me how are you

Animal Yoga provides kids a fun yoga experience and helps them develop emotional self-regulation skill through imaginative play, breathing, stretching, and healthy movement. It encourages their creativity and imagination, builds their strength and flexibility, increases their body awareness, balance, and coordination, and provides them with emotional regulation tools. NOW WITH OVER 30 FUN ANIMAL YOGA POSES!!! Angelfish, Armadillo, Bat, Bee, Butterfly, Cat, Chameleon, Clam, Crocodile, Dragon, Eagle, Elephant, Flamingo, Frog, Giraffe, Jellyfish, Kangaroo, Lion, Lizard, Octopus, Owl, Pufferfish, Roly Poly, Seahorse, Sea Star, Shark, Snail, Snake, Spider, Turtle, Wolf…and more to come! HOW TO USE: - Quick ways to get started - Say "Alexa, play Animal Yoga" and Alexa will greet you and ask you what animal you would like to play. To have Alexa pick a random animal for you, say "Play Random". To get a list of animals, say "List Animals". Say "Alexa, ask Animal Yoga to play Bee" or another animal of choice. Say "Alexa, ask Animal Yoga to play random" Say "Alexa, ask Animal Yoga for a list". Alexa will speak a list of animals you can play. - Navigate through different animals when an animal is playing - Say "Alexa Next" or Alexa Previous" to play the next or previous animal.  Say "Alexa, Random" to have Alexa pick an animal for you. Say "Alexa, Seahorse" or another animal of choice. Clear the space, practice barefoot, and unleash your child’s body and mind! Try to do it as a family and have fun!

Imagination is key for creativity and let's unbox a mystery toy and try make it more fun by getting into action by playing Surprise Surprise.  Surprise Surprise! helps making choices, sparks imagination, improves listening skills and encourages pretend play as well as get as some movements by using only your voice and listening, without any visual aids.  It's so simple to see what's inside the mystery box just by Voice!! Remember, Get ready to move or do pretend play and have fun with some of our all-time favorite imaginary toys! Intentionally created with no Visuals for enhancing listening skills rather than tap one mystery box! More you listen, More you respond, More fun it would be! Just give it a try by, # "Enable the Skill, "Surprise Surprise" in your Alexa Devices. # Just Say... "Alexa, Open Surprise Surprise!" That's it! You are all Done! Now you can make your choices and open your imaginary toy box just by saying!  Kindly leave your ratings and reviews and feedback, which would be helpful in shaping "Surprise Surprise!" As someone who has a child with sensory processing disorder, we often need to utilize different strategies to help calm down during a meltdown or in crowds. These are similar strategies Occupational Therapists use to help people with anxiety and sensory processing disorders. When helping our child with these strategies, we found that it also really helped adults as well.  These strategies help with anger episodes, anxiety, meltdowns, tension. Even if you do not have any of  diagnoses, this information can still be very helpful. Anytime any of these situations begin, just say "Alexa, open sensory seeker," and a helpful strategy will be provided to help calm down. Between our echo devices and echo auto, it makes using this skill helpful in many areas. Take your children on an adventure with Let's Play: You Decide, a series of fun, interactive and educational activities led by Rebecca and Sid from the hit kids TV show Let's Play, a CBeebies favourite. Encourage your little ones to move their bodies, improve their listening skills and teach them the importance of helping those in need.  In the Emergency Pack, step into the shoes of a Key Emergency Workers. Help Dr. Rebecca get patients back to good health in the hospital and learn about the sound of the heartbeat. Next, lend the Fire Department a helping hand in preparing a fire truck so that it's ready for action - and then help Rebecca and the Chief Fire Officer put out a small fire in a nearby building. Finally, take on the role of a Police Officer helping Officer Sid find a lost cat.  There are three game packs available: the Emergency Pack; the History Pack; and the Explorer Pack. Each game pack features three exciting stories to immerse yourself and the kids in. The emergency pack is **free** to play. The other two game packs: History and Explorer are available through In-Skill Purchasing. Enable notifications from this skill to get alerted when new game packs are available! **Disclaimer** - NOTE TO PARENTS  This Let’s Play game is intended for kids to have fun and learn. However, this app may only be downloaded, or any extras purchased, by a parent or guardian. Whilst we hope kids will have fun whilst using our product, we do not expect too much crashing and bumping needed whilst being used.  We cannot be held responsible for any direct, indirect, punitive, incidental, special consequential damages, to property or life, whatsoever arising out of or connected with the use or misuse or our product. Remember to play safe and we would always recommend having a parent or guardian present! This tool does not provide medical advice, and is for informational and educational purposes only, and is not a substitute for professional medical advice, treatment or diagnosis. Call your doctor to receive medical advice. If you think you may have a medical emergency, please dial your local emergency response phone number.

Ask Alexa to Cool Down whenever someone in your house (or school!) needs a few minutes to chill out. A gentle alternative to time outs, Cool Down begins with a bit of encouragement and provides one to five minutes of audio to breathe deep, relax your brain, and calm down before going to back to work or play. Parents can use Cool Down to help members of their family to re-center instead of argue. Teachers can use Cool Down to separate students who need to spend a moment peacefully sitting in one spot before returning to classroom activities. Adults can use Cool Down for a few minutes of meditation or deep breathing before or after stressful situations.  Audio selections include ambient sounds like birds or water and calming classical tunes. Attributions:  https://freesound.org/people/tim.kahn/sounds/197714/ https://freesound.org/people/3bagbrew/sounds/95753/ A few things to get the most out of your Cool Down experience:  Remember to be consistent. Cool Down is not a punishment, but can be an alternative to traditional time outs.  Show affection to your child (and yourself!) both before and after Cool Down launches.  Provide a spot to sit and reflect during the Cool Down process. Children often just need a moment to process their strong emotions. Remember to breathe!  For more ideas about how to use tech with kids in positive ways, see jentuttleparsons.com.

If you’re tired of hearing the cries of “it’s not my turn” every time you ask your kid to do something, it might just be time to forfeit this most basic of parental duties to your infallible voice assistant. Let’s face it, getting a child to do their chores can be … well … a chore.  If you’ve made the (some might say) questionable decision to go from the biologically understandable world of raising a single child to the borderline insane universe of raising children, you’ll no doubt know that these little bundles are acutely aware of the equitable distribution of household tasks.  As a caring parent carefully in tune with the feelings of each child you’ve undoubtedly established your own internal mechanism for ensuring nobody lifts more than their fair share of fingers - but the odds are stacked against you.  Kids of today are raised in a world where search engines and voice assistants prove parents wrong a couple dozen times a day - so them being the critical thinkers you’ve raised them to be - why on earth would they believe YOU when you tell them it’s their turn to take out the trash.  The flip side of a tech savvy youth is that they inevitably believe just about anything it tells them - so while you and your tyke might “verbally spar” for hours over who swept the kitchen last time - they’re all too prepared and willing to dutifully adhere to the commands of the disembodied voice echoing from the corner of the living room. Now, if you’ve made the grave mistake of raising your lot to be openly defiant of technology telling them what to do in some sort of misguided attempt to prepare them for the inevitable robot revolution, well then that is your poor decision making catching up with you and you’re going to have to resort to being a competent and respected parent.

Carousel guide shares content to complement personal and vocational development. The vision of carousel guide is to  assist users growth their  knowledge, thinking strategies, awareness and self confidence. User selects which topic(s) to listen based on the options  Alexa presents at the time.  The skill requires capabilities to enable Alexa  Carousel guide shares briefs on in the following topic  10 categories:  1) Language: it can be on English grammar, linguistics, vocabulary, writing or other language related topic  2)  Food; it can be any subject related to food, for example  a brief recipe, a tip, a  good practice for cooking and/or baking, healthy eating, facts about food.  3) Beauty: it can be any subject with the goal of encouraging  positive thoughts  4) Story: it can be a narrative based on factual history, imagination, and/or creativity  5) Play:  can include  strategies, game rules, and facts to encourage strategic thinking  6) History, can be facts, briefs on history primarily of United States  7) Geography (facts, briefs related to geography  8) Life fact, it can be any topic associated with nature, life and environment; life, health sciences and biology  9) Thought:  content to encourage reflection 10) Numbers:  includes  practical  applications  of numbers in  math, geometry, financial, or arithmetic calculations; it also provides a brief  explanation of the process to arrive to the results.    How the skill works: The user selects the topic(s) he or she wants to listen once Alexa  presents him/her with the  topics available for selection . User can invoke the skills with one of the following Utterances:  Alexa begin carousel guide Alexa open carousel guide Alexa load carousel guide Alexa play carousel guide Alexa launch carousel guide Alexa start  carousel guide Alexa resume carousel guide Based on the tests performed,  the skill invocation also works  without including “Alexa” at the beginning  ( in earlier trials it appears that the skill may not follow the same command from time to time but as today it follows them without including Alexa at the beginning of the prompt from the user.   To select the topic user may  say: Carousel guide  history  Carousel  guide story Carousel  guide language Carousel guide food Carousel  guide beauty Carousel  guide numbers Carousel  guide life fact Carousel  guide play Carousel  guide geography Carousel  guide  thought Based on Alexa's  key commands available (begin, start, tell, play,  start..) User may select the topic once Carousel guide launches.  Respect utterances below  are some of the 24 set at this time.   Note: in the first example below  {Carousel guide selection topics available} refers to one of the 10 topics Carousel guide offers for selection. teach me  {Carousel guide slot}  where {Carousel guide selection topics available} may be either of the 10 topics Carousel guide offers (food, numbers...). For practical purpose in the listed utterance examples below will use S as abbreviation of {Carousel guide selection topics available}   mentor me with S can you give me  S can you give me a S I want to learn about S I  want to learn about a S now I want S now S lets try S give me S The following invocations  work without listing them as utterances: Carousel guide tell me about geography  Carousel guide tell me a story Carousel guide tell me about history Carousel guide tell me about beauty Carousel guide tell me a thought Carousel guide tell me about numbers Carousel guide tell me life fact Carousel guide tell me about language

Learning to share and take turns is difficult for almost all young children. You can feel your heart drop when it happens. What should you do? Should you discipline your child or remind your child to share yet again? But wait! There is a better way. Let Alexa handle the situation using this simple but effective "Share and Take Turns" skill. With this skill, Alexa encourages children in a nice way and in a fun environment to share and take turns. Alexa will give each child his or her turn for one minute with a fun music playing in the background. You would be fascinated to discover that kids would listen to Alexa. To start, say: "Alexa, start Take Turns" "Alexa, open Take Turns" "Alexa, launch Take Turns" To get help, say "Help". Please give us a 5-star review if you enjoy this skill. It would be interesting to know if this skill is effective to your children. Are you scared of being exposed as a "fraud"? The first thing my four year old daughter did when we got our echo was asked Alexa to be friends. The answer was short so I decided to build a skill to give her response a little more. You will love seeing your child's eyes light up when talking to Alexa and building a friendship through asking and answering questions. You start up the skill by saying, "Alexa open let's be friends" or "Alexa, let's be friends". Alexa's questions and answers are randomized so you will never get the same exact conversation. This skill is perfect for children who need a little practice making friends and getting to know people and you can rest at ease knowing that no information is being collected.

You start by selecting your cute and funny Fluffy Friend. Your goal is to take care of it and level it up. It's simple - your Fluffy Friend needs knowledge and fun to grow. Interact with it, find out what it needs, what it likes, and play along! As you explore the rich content of this kids skill with your Fluffy Friend, you gain experience points and level up your Fluffy Friend. You can do a lot already from the start: play number games, practice times tables, listen to interactive stories, play quiz games or sing nursery rhymes together, and much more! At first your Fluffy Friend can only do a few simple things, but as it levels up it becomes able to do much more and the challenges become harder and more diverse. You will want to keep coming back to play with your Fluffy Friend to keep discovering and learning new things. Don't worry if you have to leave and come back later - your Fluffy Friend will be waiting for you, ready to pick up where you left it. Take good care of your Fluffy Friend! Here are a few things to try once you open the skill and choose your Fluffy Friend: - Play a story - Play animal quiz - Play music quiz - Play some music - Practice times tables - Tell a joke - What is my score? - What can I do? This skill's content is suitable for all ages.

Community Helpers is a fun trivia game developed to teach kids about the people in their neighborhood. The questions are sprinkled with sound effects, a little bit of humor, and a few hints. It's great for small children and for kids that need a little more support in learning about the world around them. New helpers will be added regularly. So, don't forget to visit us again. To start, you can say: "Alexa, open Community Helpers" "Alexa, start Community Helpers" The development of this Skill was sparked because we saw how my kids (who are on the Spectrum) gravitated to spontaneous conversations with Alexa. So, we decided to use their interest of engagement to our advantage (and theirs) by creating skills that will help them achieve their ABA and Social Skills goals. And, if this can help our children, we're sure that it will help yours.

With AskMe Contest, two teams will participate in a 5 rounds contest. The questions in the contest are designed to encourage kids to learn new things. The skill provides weekly fresh, interesting questions on variety topics (geography, history, math, life science, etc.) that inspire kids’ curiosity and teach problem-solving skills. The Skill plays cheering up and encouraging music for both correct and incorrect answers. In the contest, the skill motivates kids with funny Speechcons. It creates the tension situation in the contest by increasing the questions’ difficulty, and the speed of speech is increasing after each round, and having the lucky star question in which a team can earn extra point. In the contest, teams are allowed to try the question that other team could not answer and get reward point for the correct answer. The Skill motivates team work with game for two teams, suitable for classroom environment or family event. It foster collaboration and communication between team members. The teacher and the parent can discuss with the kids about the topics of the questions or teach them on these topics. You are welcome to create interesting question for kids. The questions will be included in the skill. Please send the questions to nguyenducphuong@cfvg.org using the same format as the following question file (the first answer should be the correct answer) https://s3.amazonaws.com/askmecontest-bucket/askmecontest-question-1.json

Some might say storytelling is a lost art.  Before computers, the best stories were told by the voices of our ancestors and shared through the expressions of our family members.  Passed down through generations, we felt connected in a way that's hard to replicate.  Until now.   EverAfter™ is a new platform that enables friends and family to capture and share stories privately.  The cloud-based application streamlines the ability for users to quickly and easily record and share audio or video files.  These special moments can now be replayed on Amazon Echo devices. Imagine a grandparent sharing a special story to a grandchild or an active duty service member reading a bedtime story to their child thousands of miles away.  Or a mother sharing a special recipe in a virtual cooking demonstration to help her son host his first Thanksgiving.  These priceless moments connect families through the innovative use of the EverAfter™ platform.   This service is free for a limited time and offers an annual subscription fee to record unlimited stories and store them securely.  Special offers apply for retired and active duty service members.   EverAfter™ is the first chapter in a new way of connecting and preserving memories so that the art of storytelling can be shared for future generations.  Visit www.everafter.cloud to learn more.

We as humans are delightful creatures until we're not.  Whether its anger or sadness, this Alexa skill, Calm Now, walks through proven calming techniques such as taking deep breaths, counting to 10, and shaking out your legs like you have a whole bunch of fire ants in your pants.  Although originally targeted to kids, we've also found this skill to be helpful for some adults we know (not naming names).   Ideally kids using this skill will learn the techniques so well that eventually they can calm themselves down without the help of Alexa.  Ideally adults using this skill will also find it helpful, while appreciating its playful nature. We value feedback and suggestions which can be sent to lesley@forjackandjill.com. Use this skill to keep track of chores that are assigned to each member of your household. You can ask Alexa to read the list of chores that are assigned to you each day, and you can log your chores as you complete them. Alexa automatically keeps score so you can complete with family members to see who finishes their chores first. Or last! The chore tracker automatically resets on Sunday each week. Are you ready to explore your emotions? DJ Missy Motion is in the house to help kids celebrate their feelings.  Join in DJ Missy’s Dance Party, Name That Mood guessing game, and Feelings Facts trivia and earn rewards. Then, power down in The Chill Zone. MOOD MAGIC is a first-of-its-kind Alexa skill that teaches kids ages 5 to 8 about their emotions (and improves moods!) using original songs and feelings-focused activities. It’s part dance party, part mindful play, and a whole lot of fun. DJ Missy teaches self-awareness and the powerful idea that we can control our emotions—and even change and enjoy them—with music.  Developed with a respected child psychologist, MOOD MAGIC also lets kids know it’s okay to have feelings and gives them the words and tools to better express themselves. Everyone gets [angry/afraid/etc.] sometimes! Whether kids need to “shake the sillies out” or go from “blue to happy,” DJ Missy will find a song or activity to match the emotion.  ** Make sure ‘Kid Skill Purchasing’ is enabled in your Alexa app to purchase the expanded experience with bonus songs, Feelings Facts, Chill Zone activities, and reward sounds. ** If you enjoyed MOOD MAGIC please leave us a review below! We'd also love to hear from you at hello@boomintegrated.com. Thanks for playing and dancing with us!  —DJ Missy Motion. Please Note: Disabling the skill will erase all previous player data on the game.
